item.description:
First published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #110, Hastings, 1066 is a tactical simulation of the confrontation between William the Bastard, Duke of Normandy, and King Harold Godwineson of Wessex... a battle that forever changed the face of the world, as the victor became King.

The game includes a 12 page rulebook, 200 counters and a 22"X34" mapsheet, which includes player displays, charts, and tables.

The Norman's objective was to reach and take London. Harold's army blocked the only road. If the Norman player controls all of the road hexes on Senlac Hill, they win a Strategic victory. The Normans also win if they can eliminate all of the Saxon housecarle units. If neither of these victory conditions occur by the end of the second assault phase, the Saxon player wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This game is an operational simulation of the American Revolutionary War from late 1775 (the siege of Boston and the two Canadian expeditions) through the end of 1781. The British player must try to stop the revolt by trying to control half a continent.

Included are a 16 page rulebook, 22"X34" map, 200 counters, and various player charts and tables.

The British player wins in one of two ways. If the year is 1775 or 1776, the British player requires control of a limited number of objectives (Canada, Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Charleston, and one area of operations). If the game continues to 1781, the British player must control New England, the Middle Colonies, the South, and either Canada or the Western Territories. If the British do not attain these objectives, the American player wins.

name.value: Thunder at Luetzen: Opening Battles for Germany, 1813

item.description:
The Thunder at Luetzen game is an army level simulation of the opening of Napoleon's 1813 campaign in Germany. The game was first published in Strategy & Tactics magazine #99.

THe game consists of a 16 page rulebook, one 22"X34" mapsheet, 200 counters and various player aids.

Leadership and morale play an important part of the game. Combat is by strength differential. If neither the French nor Allied army is demoralized by the end of 32 game turns, the French player wins if he controls Leipzig Bridge, otherwise the Allied player wins.

name.value: Warsaw Rising: Revolt of the Polish Underground, 1944

item.description:
This game is a simulation of the Polish resistance in Warsaw during 1944. The game was originally published in Strategy & Tactics magazine (#107).

The game includes a 16 page rulebook (covering all aspects of guerrila warfare and resistance combat), 200 counters (representing the units and weapons involved in the conflict) and a 22"X34" map of the City of Warsaw.

Two scenarios are provided: Warsaw Rises! (August 1944 - 4 turns) and The German Juggernaut (September, 1944 - 5 turns). Victory is based on capturing or assaulting various buildings in the city, eliminating enemy units, and (for the German player) maintaining a supply line through Warsaw. Points may also be spent during the game for additional reinforcements. The player with the most victory points at the end of the scenario, wins.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #2: Battle of the Bulge

item.description:
2nd of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around tank combat in World War 2.

link.value: World War 2: Battle of the Bulge

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #3: The Battle of Sekigahara

item.description:
3rd of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in Japan in 1600.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #4: The Battle of Britain

item.description:
4th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in World War 2, with Britain fighting the Germans in the skies.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #5: The Battle of Kawanakajima

item.description:
5th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around a battle in medieval Japan that took place in 1561.

6th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers D-Day, of course.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #7: The Siege of Osaka in the Summer
The Sierge of Osaka in the Summer

item.description:
7th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the Siege of Osaka in 1615 (in the summer!). The Summer Battle was actually a field battle-the siege of the Castle had taken place over the Winter of 1614-15. The official English title on the box is "The Sierge of Osaka in the Summer", but "Sierge" is a typo/mistranslation on their part.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #8: Battle of the Midway

item.description:
8th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around airplane combat in the Pacific Ocean between America and Japan during World War 2.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #9: Battle of Nagashino

item.description:
9th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in 1575 Japan. One interesting aspect of the battle simulated was that there was a traitor who switched sides early in the fight. In the game, if his side takes 3 of more casaulties in turn 1, he switches sides immediately. If not, he remains loyal throughout the game.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #10: Battle of Pearl Harbor

item.description:
10th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the bombing of Pearl Harbor in World War 2.

name.value: Epoch Wargame Electronics #11: Battle of Dannoura

item.description:
11th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers a battle in Japan, in the year 1185.

12th and final of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around infantry and tank combat in the desert during World War 2.

Tet `68 is a simulation of the 1968 Tet Offensive in Vietnam. The objective of the game is to show what happened during the campaign, how the U.S. and its allies, despite winning a military victory, were defeated psychologically and politically.

Included are a large 22" x 34" map of Vietnam, 200 counters, and extensive 16 page rulebook, including rules for intelligence, logistics, and weather.

Victory is awarded based on points, which are earned in different ways for the Communist and U.S. players. Communist points are scored for political successes; U.S. points are primarily scored for military objectives. At the end of 7 game turns, the player with the highest victory point total is the winner.

name.value: Cortes: Conquest of the Aztec Empire

item.description:
A two-player wargame that covers the epic three month siege of Tenochtitlan, the climactic battle for control of Mexico, fought in 1521. 
14 pages of rules, 144 5/8" counters, and a 22" x 34" map are included.

This game is the only one that I am aware of that includes rules for Human Sacrifice...

If Cortes is killed or captured, the Aztec player wins immediately. Otherwise, the Spanish player must keep his "Loss Points" to a minimum... as long as the Spanish player does not gain 17 or more points, they win.

Shogun Triumphant is a two-player historical simulation of the most famous land battle in Japanese history: The Battle of Sekigahara.

Included are a 14 page booklet of rules, charts and tables, a 22" x 34" map of the battlefield, and 158 counters.

Units are broken into factions and clans... one player commands the Eastern Army, the other player commands the West. Extensive rules for Melee Combat, Clan Effectivenes, and Defections are provided.

Victory is determined by counting loss of "Stalwartness Points". The first player to drop 160 points due to losses and defections, loses the game. If the game manages to last eight turns, without either player losing, the Western player is assumed to win.

Antietam: Burnished Rows of Steel is a game of the bloodiest single-day battle in the American Civil War.

Game turns are sequential, with each player moving, firing artillery, and then having two rounds of combat, each in turn. Also provided are rules for solitaire play.
Victory is determined by victory points earned by the Union player for capturing and maintaining control of geographical objectives and Confederate unit losses. If the Confederate player can hold the Union to less than 25 points, they win. Victory conditions are slightly different for the Solitaire game.

First published in Command magazine No. 22 (May-June 1993).

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 hour
Hex: 250 yards
Unit: Brigade & Battery

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
Two countersheets (304 5/8" counters)
One 36 page rule booklet

name.value: Desert Storm: The Mother of All Battles

item.description:
Ths game is a one- or two-player operational simulation of the Gulf War. It focuses almost exclusively on the Coalition ground war that liberated Kuwait and shattered the occupying Iraqi army.

The game includes a 22" x 34" hex map of the significant terrain in the Kuwaiti Theatre of Operations, 192 counters, and 20 pages of rules, charts, and tables.

Rules are split into both a basic and an advanced game. There are separate rules for solitaire play.

The U.S./Coalition player must completely liberate Kuwait to have a chance to win. If Kuwait is liberated within 12 game turns, the player who has gained the most 'points' in inflicting losses on their opponent, wins. The Coalition player must be aggressive in order to completly clear Iraqi units from all Kuwaiti cities, towns, oilfields, and airfields, otherwise the Iraqi player will win.

This is a simulation of the fighting in and around the capital of Hungary in January 1945.

The game is played for 14 turns and ends either with a political victory (control of Budapest) or a victory on points (given for destruction of opposing units).

It includes 16 pages of rules, a 22" x 34" mapsheet, two player aid cards, and 165 counters.

What if the Americans did not develop the atom bomb? Would they have invaded Japan?

The game includes a 20 page rulebook, a 22 x 34" mapsheet, and 200 counters.

The U.S./Allied force is primarily trying to capture Japanese cities, thus denying that side the population and industrial base necessary to carry on the war. The Japanese are trying to inflict maximum casualties on the Allied force to demoralize them.

Four different scenarios are provided, each with their own set of victory conditions. A Victory Point Index is provided for each player to keep track of their points (range 1-100)... various rules take effect when the index is at various levels for each player. There are extensive rules for gaining and losing points (over one page of rules).

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This is the hypothetical invasion on the Roman Empires of both the east and west, on the part of the hordes of the Huns.

Two elements essential to the game are the policy of alliances with other barbaric peoples (along with the activities of Pope Leo) and the calculation of cultivatable land devastated by the hordes of “Flagellum Dei”
Degree of difficulty: 2/6

Contents:

 Pieces representing the barbarian hordes and the roman legions of the eastern and western empires.
 6 heavy cards to be used to establish the outcome of combat.
 6 heavy cards to be used to resolve diplomatic conflicts.
 Combat and diplomacy tables.
 Calendar with entries and deaths of various leaders and emperors subdivided into seasons.
 Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
 Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
 Plastic storage tray and one die.

This game is a two-player simulation of the Third Servile War, a slave revolt that shook the Roman Republic from 73-71 B.C.

Included in the game are 14 pages of rules, 189 5/8" counters, and a 22" x 34" mapsheet with the areas of Italy and the Mediterranean where the War of the Gladiators took place.

Barring the occupation of Rome (for the Rebel player) or the capture of Spartacus (for the Roman player), which would give an automatic victory, the game is played for points. At the end of 17 Turns, the player with the most points wins.

link.value: Pyrrhic Victory: Legion vs. Phalanx, 280-275 B.C.

item.description:
This game is a simulation of the battle which took place between Lee's Army of Northern Virginia and Meade's Army of the Potomac at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania during the first four days of July 1863. 
Included in the game are a 22 x 34" mapsheet, 200 counters, and 18 pages of rules.

To win the game, the Confederate player must inflict heavy casualties on the Union army and/or move his own train off the map to the southwest. The Union player must resist the Confederates drive while inflicting heavy losses on the Confederates.

name.value: Port Arthur: A Short Victorious War

item.description:
Port Arthur is a simulation of the ground campaign of the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-05. 
Included in the game are 10 pages of rules, a 22" x 34" mapsheet, and 101 counters.

Victory points are awarded for causing enemy casualties, and for control of Liaoyang, Mukden, and Port Arthur (which is worth 2 points). At the beginning of the game the Russian player will be receiving 4 points per turn, so it is imperative for the Japanese player to be aggressive. At the end of 10 complete turns, the player with the higher total, wins.

Czechoslovakia 1938, This game is a two-player wargame that simulates what might have been the first campaign of World War II in Europe if the Prague government rejected the Munich Diktat.

The game was first published as a supplement to Command magazine Issue #24.

To win, the German player must attempt to crush Czechoslovakia by conquering crucial territory before France and England decide to join the war. The Czech player wins by holding out until those two Allies intervene.

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 7.5 miles / 12 km
Unit: Regiments to Divisions

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (176 5/8" counters - 142 for Czechoslovakia 1938, the rest are errata counters for other games)
One 28 page Rulebook

From the Publisher:

Behind the stunning artistry of Duel of Ages lies an epic, deeply intriguing strategy game that will capture your attention for years to come. Build the uniquely modular game map (using the PAKIT board game system) to your own advantage, thwarting the enemy's attempt to do the same.

Accept a random roster of heroic characters, each with radically different abilities. Discover a way to turn this diverse group into an effective team. To survive, your team must acquire strange and deadly equipment by confronting the illusionary guardians of the labyrinths. But through every minute of play, the enemy will be uncomfortably close, hounding your team as you hound theirs...

Expanded by

 Duel of Ages Set 2: Intensity
 Duel of Ages Set 3: Vast Horizons
 Duel of Ages Set 4: Royal Tournament
 Duel of Ages Set 5: Mercenary Camp
 Duel of Ages Set 6: Field of Honor
 Duel of Ages Set 7: Ruins of Cany XII
 Duel of Ages: Masters Addendum
 Duel of Ages: Prestige Pack
 Duel of Ages: Scrye Add-On Pack

Duel of Ages Set 4: Royal Tournament
Duel of Ages Set 5: Mercenary Camp
Duel of Ages Set 6: Field of Honor

item.description:
Up to 5 expeditions have gotten lost in the thick, impenetrable jungle.

Who will be the first person to leave this jungle unscathed? The successful person must find and make use of e- and m -business cards hidden in the mysterious pyramids of the jungle. Who will be the smartest player and reach the pyramids as quickly as possible? Who will be lucky enough to avoid meeting their fate and not succumb to swamps, floods, unfamiliar animals, disease and strange signs? Who will use items such as cell phone, laptop, GPS system, analysis equipment, webcam and PDA on their own, or with their fellow players, in the smartest way as to establish connections, fetch help, grasp the situation, fend off hunger, find paths, get the natives on their side and interpret strange signs correctly?
 And, at the end of this exciting contest in the jungle, who will be have the good fortune and best overview to be able to tell apart the mysterious pyramids? The first person to leave the jungle with two e/m-jokers has earned our congratulations.

item.description:
Washington’s and Cornwallis’ problems for the decisive siege in the American War of Independence, reproduced on a 70x100 centimeter map, with the employment of all the American, French, Prussian and English units.

Degree of difficulty: 2/6

Contents:

 79 cut out pieces, representing American, French, English and Prussian units which took part in the battle.
 Explosion markers to show which units have been shot or damaged.
 Combat disk, to check the results of battles and of artillery fire, with calendar.
 York Town map and surroundings in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
 Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples and table of battle field forces.
 Plastic storage tray and one die.

Three games at different levels of difficulty reconstructing the most famous battle between the U.S. Army and the Indians. The three-dimensional board shows the Valley of Little Big Horn, from the high plains, just as Colonel Custer saw it before his last stand.

Degree of difficulty: 3/6

Contents:

 Pieces in matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides.
 Large cardboard table to be used to establish the outcome of combat and rifle fire.
 Board in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces.
 Relief sections in rigid, thick cardboard to be used to create the three-dimensionality of the terrain.
 Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
 Plastic storage tray and dice.

item.description:
This is the story of the great strategy used by the Germans to assure the success of their first landings in the 2nd World War. Six small tactical maps and one strategic map enable the player to follow the advance of the Germans, both on land and in the air and naval battles over the waters of the North Sea.

Degree of difficulty: 4/6

Contents:

 Calendar in cardboard used to calculate the entry of the various units into the game.
 Naval and land combat tables in cardboard printed in two colors.
 Pieces in matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides representing German, Norwegian and Allied units.
 6 tactical maps in rigid, thick cardboard with a matte plastic finish, printed in 5 colors.
 Strategic map in rigid, thick cardboard used to carry out air and naval moves.
 4 small grids to calculate moves off the map.
 Tablet for the formation of convoys and the positioning of submarines
 Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
 Plastic storage tray and dice

item.description:
Chase Across the Planes is a boardgame for two to four players set in the worlds of the Intruder. The game was published in Intruder magazine #1.

Player assume the roles of supernatural characters who are testing their powers for the first time... each character has a special ability that allows them to 'bend' the rules in a slightly different way.

Players move around a small stylized mapboard that represents the different planes of existance, attempting to visit each one and 'leave their mark'. Along the way, they may battle other characters and/or destroy other player's markers.

As soon as a player has markers in all of the planes required (depending on the number of players, this can be 4 to 6), he wins.

A quick two-player game that was published in Intruder magazine #2.

One player takes the role of Eric, the Intruder, and the other player plays the monstrous Golden Hoarde. The object for the Intruder player is to cross the map and enter the throne room, thus avoiding the Master of Chaos and winning the game. For the Golden Hoarde player to win, he must attack at any opportunity, to force Eric to lose his six starting 'life points', rendering him unconscious and subject to capture.

Two to six players deal in alternate dimensional 'real estate' in this game that was published in Intruder magazine #3.

Players move around the board trying to gain access to property in other dimensions. Players may recruit armies, fight for possession of dimensional 'real estate', plunder other players, and may have to overcome pitfalls along the way.

The first player to control points in all nine dimensions is the winner.

A two player boardgame set in the world of comic hero Agent 13. The game was published in 13: Assassin magazine #5.

Maggie Darr and her henchmen are trying to track down and kill Agent 13. At the same time, Agent 13 wants to capture Maggie Darr because she holds the secret to his past.

One player takes the role of Agent 13, the other, Maggie Darr. Agent 13 must either capture Maggie or find six clues to his past and return to his Headquarters to win. The only way that the 'Maggie' player can win is to eliminate Agent 13. There is no time limit to the game.

name.value: Maison Ikkoku: Love's Roulette (Koi no Roulette)

item.description:
Complexity level 1 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Love Attack to Kyoko in Maison Ikkoku

Tsukada takes a break from their usual 2 player science fiction wargames to make this boardgame based off the love/comedy manga (and anime) by Rumiko Takahashi. Unlike many of Tsukada's games, this actually is 2-6 players (not their usual "split up into 2 teams" multiplayer suggestion).

You have 3 markers to keep track of your attack points (as in getting the nerve to talk to her, not physically attack), your love points, and her emotion towards you. The game itself is of the roll-and-move variety, with 74 different event cards, each with scenes from the manga on them, that, along with the board spaces themselves, affect your markers.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Published in two parts in Intruder magazine #4 and #5, Interdimensional Chess is Chess with a twist.

Each game has a different theme (issue #4 is based in the world of Buck Rogers, issue #5 is based in the comic world of 'R.I.P.). Each chess piece has an additional power depending on the rules set used (e.g.-the King can move two spaces instead of one; the Succubus moves like a Bishop, but can 'fly' over friendly pieces).

Games are played like regular Chess - the object is to immobilize or 'checkmate' the opponent's king.

A simple card game for 2 to 6 players based on the world of Agent 13. The game was published in 13: Assassin magazine #4.

The game is basically a rummy-like game where some of the cards have special powers. Cards are melded to the table either in front of the person who played it or in front of an opponent. Each card has a specific number of points... either positive or negative (range -4 to +4).

The first player to have cards totaling 12 points is the winner.

A two to four player abstract tactical game published in Warhawks magazine #6.

Players take the roles of up to four terrible 'Plant People', each with a different special power. Players alternate placing their vines on the board. When a square is surrounded on three sides it forms a pod (worth 3 points in combat). Players have either 8 or 12 pods depending on their special power.

When opponent's vines touch, there is combat... loser must remove all of the vines being attacked.

The object of the game is to completely choke out all other player's vines and pods, forcing them off the board.

A solitaire game, based on the Agent 13 comic, published in 13: Assassin magazine #2.

All you have to do is get from Start' to the Agent 13 Cell by avoiding loss of life points and trying to evade as many random encounters as possible. There are more encounter tokens than game spaces, so every game is different.

A two-player boardgame based on the Agent 13 comic published in 13:Assassin magazine #3.

One player takes the role of Agent 13, the other is Agent 13's nemesis, China White, and her minions. Players alternate moving (resolving any random encounters) and then resolve any combat.

The first player to capture the power crystal and escape, or eliminate all of his opponent's characters, is the winner.

Complexity rating 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Not an expansion to any other Aura Battler game, this game is completely stand-alone.

2 player ground based tactical wargame. 3-fold out mounted maps combine to make one big map.

From the slums, where purse-snatchers and courtesans work their respective trades, to the inner salons of the Louvre, where confessors, royal astrologers, musketeers, and court favorites mingle and scheme in hushed conversations, the position of King's Jeweler has suddenly become a lot more dangerous!

Set in Paris, on the eve of the French Revolution, Queen's Necklace is a game of gem-selling, influence, and intrigue at the court. Two to four players compete in the role of royal jeweler to sell rare jewels to the Queen and her court.

Jeweler's loupe in hand, you must decide how best to spend your hard-earned ducats: acquiring beautiful gems (diamonds, emeralds, and rubies); or buying the favors of the various court followers. After three years of craftsmanship, the jeweler who sells the most precious gems and builds the largest fortune will receive the coveted title of King's Jeweler and a place at the court!

item.description:
User Review:

Each player begins with a pawn on the Start Space and a hand of four Spell-Caster cards and two Spell-Buster cards. In turn, each player will roll the six-sided die and advance that number of spaces on the game board. A player’s action is dependent on the space on which that player lands.

Players may play Spell-Caster cards against their opponents before rolling the dice. Spell-Buster cards can be played to counter Spell-Caster cards. There are some save spaces on the game board where a player can not be served with a Spell-Caster card.

The first person to reach the end of the track seizes the gold and must race back to the starting space with the gold to win! Along the way back the player may encounter the other players who may steal the gold by catching up and passing the lead player.

name.value: The Battle For Smithville II: An R.I.P. Cardgame

item.description:
The Battle for Smithville II is a two player card game. It was published in R.I.P. magazine #6.

Included in the game are rules and sheets of cut-apart cards.

Part rummy, part concentration, players play, then flip cards to match adversaries. If the adversaries battle, the player gains points. The one with the most points after all of the cards have been played, wins.

Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Mobilesuits Combat in Gundam

One of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam anime series from the early 1980s. This one has 7 different ground-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters, a pad of record sheets, and 4 double-sided maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.
